reasoning:
The critique targets the essay’s Section 2.5 hedonic-treadmill discussion and the suggestion (via 2.3.3) that a future could be a moral catastrophe despite inhabitants reporting high wellbeing. That’s a real strand of the overall case (supporting ‘fragility’ via non-obvious failure modes), but it’s not central to the essay’s main thrust, which rests on many other independent considerations (population ethics, digital beings, resource allocation, multiplicative-value model, and the Section 3 taxonomy of ‘fussy’ value functions). So centrality is modest.

On strength: the critique mostly asserts a substantive metaethical/psychological thesis (“value is intrinsically relative/prediction-error based; no view from nowhere”) and then declares objective-good talk a category error; it doesn’t directly engage the essay’s key move, which is pluralism/uncertainty across moral views plus the possibility that people adapt their preferences, making catastrophic value loss non-salient. Moreover, the essay itself already flags that the treadmill analogy could be misleading and that future dissatisfaction needn’t track moral loss, so part of the critique is somewhat ‘priced in.’ Thus it weakens the targeted passage only somewhat.

Correctness is mixed: it’s broadly plausible that human valuation involves adaptation and prediction-error mechanisms, and that subjective reports can diverge from external metrics; but stronger claims (that there is no coherent objective standpoint, that objective-list assessments are a ‘category error,’ and that optimizing objective metrics tends to wireheading) are contentious and under-argued.

Clarity is high: the objection is easy to state and identify. Dead weight is low (mostly argumentative content). It is largely a single-issue critique.
title: Relative valuation undermines the concept of objective hedonic catastrophe
